segments.text: Although I was very much personally involved in what I was doing outside the press, it was obvious that there was a lot of turmoil going on, but I did my all-power best to stay out of it.
That's the mark.
We had that ministry.
Yeah.
Let's say now, when Mary Miller comes, was there a, did you sense at that point, some kind of a relief?
Well, I should say that in 1990, I moved from the editorial department to the marketing department, so I suddenly had a completely different perspective of everything.
Now, at that point, in terms of marketing, your time was...
I had so many different titles.
I noticed everybody got kind of a soft federal title.
Yeah, because at the time, when I left the editorial department, I was the associate editor.
And when I had decided to move over here, both of the two young women working in the marketing department had both quit simultaneously.
That was Marilyn Gaeta and Sarah Oates.
And so I basically took the best parts of both of those jobs and made it.
And we got one job out of it.
And so I was primarily doing publicity, and we had a several year attempt to have me acquire and develop reissue books, which I wasn't particularly interested in doing it, but it had to be done.
So I was supposed to do that.
Second edition?
Yeah, reissues and paperback, that type of thing.
We've never really had a paperback policy that's been approved.
I really don't.
At the time that I was supposed to be acquiring the issues, Mark and me worked on developing guidelines for what we could and couldn't do.
It was a great deal of work that had nothing whatsoever to do with the other work that we were doing, that I was doing.
Completely different.
You know, it's like in the middle of the day, you know, that hat would be switching off and on.
It was tough.
Well, I didn't actually get any responsibility in the advertising media planning until a couple of years ago when Marianne was in the marketing department.
She did all of the advertising planning and she did all the advertising design.
Joan does the advertising design now, but I do all the rest of it.
Now, how do you relate to the, what is our big picture of publicity promotion?
What do you do?
Tell me, what do you do to make the press, I mean, let's say the conceptual program of the United States press?
Well, whenever the editors are getting in new manuscripts and looking at them, frequently they'll do a pre-contract circulation.
And at that point, Gail passes it to the people in the marketing department, and I look at it and I try to give an opinion as to whether it's going to have a scholarly or trade audience.

especially if it has a trade audience, if there are special things that we need to do, would need to do in advance, like get endorsements, budget extra money for advance proof, budget extra money for photographs.
And then I would also, later on, determine how many advance proof were needed and who should get them.
We should get them.
And I've developed the review list and I write them as releases.
And I contact, you know, certain individuals.
Yeah.
And that, of course, is .
Yeah, it just depends on .
Yeah, and it's always,
it becomes touchy
say if it's a book that is really popular and a lot of people want it, we'll just get hordes of requests come in and you have to winnow through them and decide.
Okay, how do they know to request that book?
Well, we send, when we send out our seasonal catalog, I have a media database and I send it out to people.
Okay, so that catalog is going to that, you know, those people in the 90s?
Yeah, they'll get through that.
Yeah.
And all of this, though, maybe I'd want to emphasize that even the reason that I shifted from editorial to marketing is because I like copywriting a great deal.
Copywriting is so completely different from being a writer because it's just wordsmithing.
It's very technical, but it's the one skill I have that I have very high confidence in.
So I write all the new books and add copy and sometimes I try to come up with new titles for the books.
Write little invitations and little headlines for the ads.
The president's giving a copy of one of our books to the graduation speaker.
He doesn't have a sentence to say with it.
They call us, and I can't think of a sentence for it.
Yeah, you're the writer.
You're the person who goes through it.
Yeah, and we do a little season-long newsletter also that I'm the untitled editor of the newsletter, which I pretty much...
Now, were there any significant changes in organization ?
None that affected me.
OK. That's all.
How about with ?
The main one that I
vocally pushed for the gala was that Marianne had moved over into the design and production area.
And so I was going to be taking over the advertising planning.
And at that point, I said, acquiring these reissues is so
Acquiring the reissue, it's so time consuming to try to do it right.
It's always a struggle to get it under the wire.
And since it's so completely different than marketing, it seems like it's more suitable to have it back in editorial.
And at the time, there was new staff members over there that seemed interested in doing it.
suggested that gail asked tom to put that back in that tutorial yeah someone's already brought that up to me
Did you see any change in the pace of activity, production level, individual style, or anything like that?
Well, I would say there was kind of a big difference.
When Mary came here, she seemed interested in having everyone work together as a team.
And whenever a meeting was held, everyone attended the meeting.
means can be time-consuming, and most of it had very little to do with what I was doing.

So it was somewhat of a relief to me that when Tom came aboard, he seemed to have a much more hierarchical style and would deal directly with the department heads who would take information to their staff, and so we didn't have to attend so many meetings anymore.
But she didn't have an appointment with her?
She couldn't.
Well, and she also, I mean, it was, I think, you know, everyone was kind of horrified at the prospect that she made us go on to that retreat in the woods.
Yeah.
Just, I guess, our feelings and all that.
Yeah.
What she had, you know.
I mean, it's all right, because there's lots of traditional friction, I'm sure, every press that crops up between departments.
And the one that marketing always remembers is that people from other departments say that marketing always
gets to go to these fun parties and to go places out of town.

The problem with that is that part of attending the party or attending the out-of-town exhibit is hauling many tons of equipment and books and equipment through the hotel laundry and kitchen and up the great elevator with the staff who can't speak English and can't tell you where to go or what floor to get off on.
So that type of stuff is hard work.
Do you see, what direction do you see the, I don't know, if you think, in your experience at Texas A&M,
What is that?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this press?
Where can we go?
How are we going?
Well, that's a big question.
Well, it relates to the reception that
Mrs. Ford, right?
First time this month.
Look at that.
To the reception at the back of the Gimbel, I've got all kinds of redoubts.
Basically, the one redoubt is, how do we know what to do here?
What did the election trust do for you in the first place?
Well, this, of course, is the research institution.
And I assume that means that the faculty are going to be judged for tenure on the basis of what they produce, depending on what department they're in, of course.
But we're here to, as our traditional mission is, to disseminate scholarship.

be their their connection to the world one of the main things i think that especially in marketing that if we have to provide a little a little dose of reality because a lot of books that come in whose authors work very hard on it and it's very enthusiastic and believes that everyone wants to buy a copy and read it and the very sad thing is that

that most people do not read books even that they borrow from the library and they certainly do not buy books and i'm talking about the general public so when so we we're in a position to say this is very good work that you've done you know it will make a tremendous contribution to scholarship but
the interested audience is not large.
You're doing a great service to a select group of people.
And it's our job to be able to identify when there is going to be a larger group of people that's both interested and that is reachable.
Because the key is in reaching them.
If there's no direct mail list for the identified audience, you're not going to be able to reach them with any surety.
Do you see, from your perspective now, independent marketing, what kind of books
What kind of books do you do best?
I mean, what discipline?
Yeah.
Character.
Yes.
What are our good books?
Successful books.
Definitely.
I admire you.
Thank you.
I mean, I personally, I gave success by, you know,
what kind of reviews it gets.
Some books get almost no reviews, and some books get a smattering of sort of positive and sort of negative reviews.
And so to me, a successful book is one that wins a lot of awards, gets the vast majority of reviews are very good, and might not necessarily sell very many copies.
But the awards and the reviews and what the author does after that was also really fun.
Because we had one author that...
published a book with us.
It probably would have a limited audience, but it got some really nice reviews in some prominent places.
And as a result of that, two other publishing companies or one other publishing company called his author and said, we're going to contract you to do another book for us.
That's success.
That's success.
It really is.
Or if the author gets a commercial house contract after publishing this.
It's too bad we wouldn't be publishing ourselves, but that shows that the first book was a success.
Well, you know, our university is a nation of publishers, in a way.
Now, in terms of the publishing business, the market's getting tougher.
Oh, absolutely.
Absolutely.
And part of it is
I remember Gail and I talking about some project that I don't remember at one time, and we were talking about its audience, and I said, well, this seems like a book mostly for an older audience.
And she said, well, if you go through our individual customer records, most of them are considerably older people.
And when I look at young people around them,
And even people who are almost as old as I am who tell me, and these are people with college educations who are in graduate school or have graduate degrees, and they say, I don't read.
I never buy books, and I never read.
And it tells me that anyone who
Because any younger than I am is not going to be oriented toward books at all.
They're just oriented toward, you know, TVs and computers.
And when we get our student interns, you know, they're even here working, you know, expressing their interest in working in the publishing house.
We get them back in the marketing department, and they just want to work on the website.
YOU KNOW, THEY'RE NOT INTERESTED IN A SMALL, YOU KNOW, ACCUMULATION OF TASKS THAT WILL LEAD TO SOME KIND OF SUCCESS.
THEY REALLY ONLY SEEM TO GET EXCITED ABOUT THAT WHEN THEY GET READY.
So that means that the future is going to be more covering than the present is.
Well, I don't have a reputation as being a bright, shiny optimist.
Yeah, I don't see it getting any bigger.
I really have to put it in a different way.
Maybe I'll have to abandon it for a while.
Well, yeah, I'm not saying it never does.
The economics of it get harder and harder and harder.
Well, I should get more.
Well, that's what I .
Part of it is external.
I think you're being looked at.
You had money.
We had money.
And why not privatize it?
That doesn't work.
You have the rights.
No, they're quite, I think, I know I've heard of which one of the big, bigger viewers of the Press is it?
Maybe California was, California has lost, I think, a lot of, you know, a lot of journals.
Yeah.
Who's that business based?
Well, I know this.
The state of California, you know, just...
You know, slashed everyone so severely.
I can't imagine the president would have escaped that.
And I didn't know I was going to be in California, but the 7th and 8th, they got 100 people.
They said, coming down here, they're going to get kind of shocked.
It was a little dingy, but a very small place.
They were probably close to 100 people.
I really, at this point, have no opinion about that.
I just use what we have at the time.
It was easier to have an opinion like that in the editorial rather than some types of projects.
Well, I couldn't pick it, you know, because I was only in a copy of its new section of it.
Some projects were of more interest or somehow more gratifying, or some authors were easier to over-direct than others.
But there are still certain projects that produce a great sense of satisfaction.
And I suppose each person has a .
Oh, yeah, depending on what it is.
Lloyd Lyman used to tell me I was only interested in pointy-headed British literary stuff.
But in actual fact, in all the years I've worked here,
involved I got in any project was the East of Chosin book, which was the Korean War Frontlines.
And that one, you know, and I even, you know, had contact with that after I moved into marketing because frequently when
people write in or call in looking for the author, and it gets fed back to the publicity area.
And I would have to say that that one book produced more, quote, fan mail or calls and letters than almost all the others combined.
You know, I even had a minister called one day and just wanted to read me something from the magazine that had to do, that mentioned that book.
And the minister just talked on and on about, you know, the profound meaning it had for these people.
And actually, I think, you know, a lot of that is timing and timing is not something you necessarily like.
Oh, no.
Well, I don't know.
I wasn't here for the entire experience of it because
The beginning of it apparently had this special quality.
Yeah, yeah.
Whereas now it's more, you know, it's just kind of a basic process.
Well, anyway, thank you.
Okay.
Okay.
Did Linda Collins tell you the story about the post office box?
I told her to do that.
No, no, tell me.
There was some kind of confusion last week about that.
The press has always had the address of 4C, the call station, and the press.
The woman just said, Tom asked her to call the post office and ask them.
And it turned out that there is no such thing as floor C. And then it turns out that there never has been.
But that when Frank Wardlaw, when arrangements were being made to start the press, and Frank Wardlaw would come, he said, I need a place to get mail.
And the university was going to set him up in the post office box for floor C.

But then, apparently, before he even got here, after he'd already commissioned Tom Lee to make that letterhead with the address in it, the university called and said something about, well, you're not going to have the post office vouchers, and you're stuck with this man.
And he supposedly said, well, I've already had his artwork commissioned.
And I found this out on Friday, last Friday, that there never was a drawer scene.
And so I'm assuming, you know, if Frank Wardlaw, and he's so legendary, I just had the idea, well, Frank Wardlaw had the drawer scene, and since it was his, you can't partner with him.
Although we have parted with it now.
Yeah, we deleted it off of our, we were working on our sale catalog.
So they said, well, you know, you really don't need to use your seed.
In fact, it confuses the campus mail or something.
I guess they look for it over there.
I don't know.
I guess Linda knows the full story of that.
Linda or Gail at one or the other.
I thought it was so funny that...
Very good.
I appreciate your time.
Okay.
And I assume you're...
I just do what I'm .
